tn.text: This word is used here to draw peoples' attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Each one will be like a shelter from the wind and a refuge from the storm
tn.text: This compares the king and princes who protect the people to a shelter. AT: "the rulers will protect the people like a shelter does in a storm" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: like streams of water in a dry place
tn.text: This is another comparison that means that the rulers will provide for the needs of the people. AT: "they will provide for the people like streams of water in a dry place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: like the shade of a great rock in a land of weariness
tn.text: This is another comparison that means that the rulers will provide comfort and rest for the people. AT: "they will provide rest for the people like a huge rock gives shade to weary people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Both of these phrases emphasize that the leaders will enable the people to understand God's truth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"will see clearly"
Isaiah continues describing the people after God restores righteous rulers in Judah. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:isa:32:01|32:1-3]])
This refers to people who act rashly and people who stutter. AT: "The rash person ... the stuttering person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

tn.ref: The fool will no longer be called honorable
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "No one will give honor to the fool" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: For the fool speaks folly, and his heart plans evil
tn.text: "The fool" refers to foolish people. Also, "folly" and "evil" may be expressed as adjectives. AT: "For the foolish person says foolish things and his heart plans evil things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here the foolish person is referred to by his heart to emphasize his inner thoughts. AT: "he plans evil things in his heart" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

This can be stated in active form. "The deceiver" refers to a person who is deceptive. AT: "nor will anyone show respect to the person who deceives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
The word "he" refers to the foolish person.

"The hungry" refers to hungry people. They are hungry because they have empty stomachs. AT: "the hungry person have an empty stomach" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: the thirsty he causes to lack drink
tn.text: "The thirsty" refers to people who are thirsty. AT: "he causes the thirsty person to have nothing to drink" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This refers to a person who deceives others. AT: "The deceptive person's" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

tn.ref: to ruin the poor with lies
tn.text: "The poor" refers to poor people. Also, the phrase "to ruin" does not means to kill them but to harm them by telling lies about them. AT: "to harm the poor people by telling lies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This means that he will be successful. AT: "he will be successful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Stand up" or "Pay attention"
"secure" or "carefree"
Isaiah is refers to himself by his voice to emphasize what he says. AT: "me speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This can be stated in active form. Also, Isaiah speaks of them no longer being confident as if their confidence were a physical object that is broken. AT: "you will no longer be confident" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This means that there would not be good grapes to harvest. AT: "there will be no grapes for you to harvest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"the time for gathering crops will not happen"
Isaiah continues speaking.
"Shake from fear"
"secure" or "carefree"

tn.ref: take off your fine clothes and make yourselves bare
tn.text: Here "bare" does not necessarily mean naked, but to wear minimal covering such as undergarments. AT: "take off you fine clothes and make yourself unclothed" or "take off your fancy clothes" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: put on sackcloth around your waists
tn.text: This is an act of grieving or mourning. AT: "put sackcloth around waists as you grieve" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: You will wail for the pleasant fields, for the fruitful vines
tn.text: This means that they will cry out loudly as they grieve what happens to their fruitful fields and vines. AT: "You will wail because of what happens to your pleasant fields and fruitful vines" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Translate this the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:05:05|5:6]].
Here the houses are described as joyful because of the joyful people in them. AT: "your houses where you were once joyful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"your joyful city." The word "revelry" means celebrating and partying.
Isaiah continues speaking.

tn.ref: For the palace will be forsaken, the crowded city will be deserted
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "For the people will forsake the palace and the crowds will abandon the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This refers to the fort built on the top of the hill. AT: "the fort on the hill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the hill and the watchtower will become caves
tn.text: This speaks of the fort and the watchtower being abandoned as if they became caves. AT: "the hill and the watchtower will become abandoned and empty" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: a joy of wild donkeys, a pasture of flocks
tn.text: This means the these animals will enjoy the grass that grows among the abandon fort and watchtower. AT: "the wild donkeys and the flocks of sheep will eat the grass there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This means a very long time. AT: "an extremely long time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "until Yahweh pours the Spirit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the Spirit is poured on us
tn.text: This speaks of Yahweh giving him Spirit to his people as if his Spirit were a liquid that he would pour on them. AT: "the Spirit is given to us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here heaven is referred to as "on high." AT: "from heaven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the fruitful field is considered as a forest
tn.text: This can be written in active form. This compares how overly bountiful the fruitful fields are by comparing them to a thick, dense forest. AT: "people will say that the fruitful fields have grown thick like a forest" or "the fruitful fields will be overly bountiful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and  [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Isaiah continues speaking.

tn.ref: justice will reside ... righteousness will live
tn.text: Isaiah describes "justice" and "righteousness" as a person who lives in these places. This means the people who live in these places will do what is just and right. AT: "people will act justly in the wilderness and people will act righteously in the fertile fields (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: The work of righteousness will be peace; and the result of righteousness, quietness and confidence forever
tn.text: These two phrases are parallel and both give results of righteousness. These can be combined. AT: "The result of people acting righteously is that there will be peace, and quietness, and confidence forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"place"
Translate this the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:28:01|28:2]].

tn.ref: the forest is destroyed, and the city is completely annihilated
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "it destroys the forest and completely destroys the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: you who sow beside all the streams will be blessed, you who who send out your ox and donkey to graze
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. This refers to Yahweh blessing all of his people and speaks of the things that are normal for his people to do. AT: "Yahweh will bless you, as you plant your crops in fields alongside the streams and as you send out your ox and donkey to graze in the pasture" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
